name: Module 1
description: Help students understand the concept of grouping and repeated grouping.

standards.description: Use addition to find the total number of objects arranged in rectangular arrays with up to 5 rows and up to 5 columns; write an equation to express the total as a sum of equal addends
Interpret the products of whole numbers, such as interpreting 5 Ã— 7 as the total number of objects in 5 groups of 7 objects each.

activities.name: Starting off
activities.description: This activity introduces students to the basic pieces of the UI: Blocks, the page, and the view.
reflections: Well done! You ran the code! This is the reflect box. It gives you tips and helps you know what you have learned. Click the Next button to learn more.
You have learned how to drag the blocks onto the page.
Look at the blocks. When you have dragged all of the blocks onto the page they change color.
Click Done to go to the next activity.
activities.prompt: Drag a <define word='circle_block'>circle block</define> onto the page. Then press the <define word='run_button'>run button</define> at the bottom of the page.

activities.name: Connecting blocks together
activities.description: This introduces the concept of connecting two blocks together.
activities.prompt: Drag two <define word='circle_block'>circle blocks</define> onto the page and <define word='connect_block'>connect</define> them together. Press the <define word='run_button'>run button</define>.
reflections: By <define word='connect_block'>connecting</define> the two blocks you told the computer to draw a circle. You have written code!

activities.name: Connecting multiple blocks together
activities.description: Learn about connecting multiple blocks together
activities.prompt: Tell the computer to draw 5 circles by <define word='connect_block'>connecting</define> 5 <define word='circle_block'>circle blocks</define> together.
reflections:
We are telling our computer to add. In this case, our math sentence looks like this:

1 circle + 1 circle + 1 circle + 1 circle + 1 circle = 5 circles.

activities.name: The Repeat Block
activities.description: Learn about the repeat block. In this activity you will observe the default behavior of the repeat block. You should expect it to repeat the action inside it the number of times found in the input.
activities.prompt: Drag a <define word='repeat_block'>repeat block</define>  onto the page and then then place a <define word='circle_block'>circle block</define> inside of the <define word='repeat_block'>repeat block</define>.
reflections: We just told the computer to do the same thing as last time. This time we only used three blocks.

activities.name: Adjusting the Repeat Block
activities.description: Learn how to adjust the repeat block.
activities.prompt: Tell the computer to draw 7 circles using the <define word='repeat_block'>repeat block</define> by changing the number 5 on the <define word='repeat_block'>repeat block</define> to 7.

activities.name: A lot of repeating
activities.description: Learn about placing one repeat block inside another one.
activities.prompt:
Tell the computer to draw 5 groups of 5 circles.
  1. To do this, place one of the repeat blocks inside another repeat block.
  2. Then place a circle block into the second repeat block.
reflections: We have just taught our computer to do <define word='repeated_addition'>repeated addition</define>.
A row is from side to side like standing in a line. It looks like this:
We have 5 rows with 5 circles in each row. Each row has the same number of items.
A column is from up and down like climbing a ladder. It looks like this:
We also have 5 columns with 5 circles in each column. Each column has the same number of items.
Repeated addition is also called <define word='multiplication'>multiplication</define>.
<define word='multiplication'>Multiplication</define> is where we take groups of equal sizes and add all of their items together.

activities.name: Multiplying using the repeat block
activities.description: Modify the defaults of the nested repeat blocks
activities.prompt: Now, letâ€™s <define word='multiplication'>multiply</define>. Place one <define word='repeat_block'>repeat block</define> inside the other one. Then place the <define word='circle_block'>circle block</define> inside the second <define word='repeat_block'>repeat block</define>. Change the <define word='repeat_block'>repeat block</define> numbers to 3 and 4.
reflections: There are 3 rows with 4 circles in each row.
By counting the circles we know that there are 12 circles total.

activities.name: Multiplying
activities.prompt: Doing the same thing as before, tell the computer to <define word='multiplication'>multiply</define> by making it repeat 4 circles 3 times.
reflections: 3 rows of 4 circles make the same number of circles as 4 rows of 3 circles.
By counting all the circles we know that there are 12 circles again. That was the same as last time.
In math we say it like this: 3 times 4 equals 12, and we write it like this: 3 x 4 = 12.
This means that we have 3 groups of 4 items and 12 items in total.
If we had 5 groups of 3 items, we would write it like this: 5 x 3.

To get our computer to do this for us we would use 2 <define word='repeat_block'>repeat blocks</define> like before. Then we would modify the first <define word='repeat_block'>repeat block</define> to have 5 as its value and the second <define word='repeat_block'>repeat block</define> would have 3 as its value.

activities.name: Applying multiplication
activities.prompt: Use <define word='coding'>coding</define>. Find the value of the missing number. 5 x 3 = ____.
reflections: You have written the correct code. Well done! Think about what the answer is and then click next.
The correct answer is 15.

circle_block.name: Circle Block
circle_block.definition-html: A code block that draws a circle

connect_block.name: Connect
connect_block.definition-html: Make one block attach to another block

repeat_block.name: Repeat Block
repeat_block.definition-html:
This block is made up of two parts.
  1. Number Input: this tells us how many times we should run the code inside the code slot
  2. Code Slot: The area we can put other code blocks.
This block allows us to do one thing many times

multiplication.name: Multiplication, Multiply
multiplication.definition-html: This is similar to repeated addition. We add up one or more groups with equal items in each group.

coding.name: Coding
coding.definition-html: Creating instructions for a computer to read. This is how we tell computers what to do.

run_button.name: Run Button, Run
run_button.definition-html: The button that tells the computer to make our code do something.
